nodes.text: Input-aware selective instruction duplication (SID) that adapts protection to runtime inputs can mitigate silent data corruption (SDC) coverage loss of existing input-agnostic SID while remaining lightweight and efficient (Protego proposal)
Existing SID methods are input-agnostic: they derive instruction vulnerability profiles from a default reference input and assume invariance across inputs

Fault injection (FI) experiments across multiple inputs show significant shifts in SDC propagation and large SDC coverage loss when static SID derived from a reference input is applied to other inputs (e.g., coverage drops from 43% to 29% for Pathfinder example)

Protego framework: a one-time offline FI-guided input search to find representative inputs, grouping inputs by SID protection similarity, precomputing representative SID-protected executables per group, and a lightweight runtime mapping using input-argument features and an MLP to select the appropriate executable

Offline guided search: generate and evaluate 500 unique inputs using mutation/crossover from seeds, score inputs by SDC vulnerability deviation, and run FI per explored input to obtain instruction-level vulnerability profiles

Input grouping: cluster the 500 explored inputs by minimizing maximum SDC coverage loss within groups, use a 10% allowable coverage-loss threshold to obtain a small number of input groups and pick a representative input (median SDC rate) per group, then generate and store representative SID-protected executables

Runtime mapping features and model: extract lightweight transformed argument-level features (select top 5 via mutual information), train an MLP regressor (five hidden layers 512-256-128-64-32, ReLU, Adam) on 500 examples to predict overall SDC vulnerability and map new inputs to groups without runtime FI or dynamic profiling

Protego substantially reduces average SDC coverage loss across diverse inputs compared to existing SID: reported reduction from about 21% average loss to about 10% average loss (evaluation across 10 HPC applications)

Measured evaluation: over 100 online inputs across 10 applications, baseline mean SDC coverage loss at multiple protection budgets averaged ~23.8% (10% overhead) whereas Protego averaged ~15.2% (10% overhead); Protego consistently yields lower mean loss across tested overheads

Protego runtime is lightweight: selecting the appropriate representative SID executable takes about 0.05 seconds per input versus roughly 5 seconds for full duplication deployment, yielding about 100x runtime speedup
Offline cost is significant but one-time: input search takes on average ~3500 minutes, SID evaluation for representative groups ~880 minutes, and MLP training ~6 seconds per application

Case study on high SDC-prone inputs: baseline SID experiences large coverage loss (average 22.89%) while Protego reduces that loss substantially (average 6.41%), demonstrating Protego's advantage for inputs that activate previously unprotected vulnerable regions
Assumption: the number of distinct SID protection variants induced by input variations is small enough that a handful of representative groups can cover the input space effectively

Supporting observation: empirical grouping results show the number of input groups declines sharply as allowable maximum SDC coverage loss increases; at a 10% threshold only a few groups exist per application, validating the grouping assumption

Limitation and future opportunity: offline FI-guided search repeats similar profiles in later stages suggesting potential to reduce offline cost by reusing SDC profiles instead of injecting for every explored input

Conclusion: Protego enables practical input-aware SID by combining a one-time offline vulnerability-guided exploration with lightweight runtime input-feature mapping, improving SDC coverage across inputs without runtime FI or heavy profiling
